block.p: Thatcher Contradicts Party On Touchy Issue of Europe Former Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher took center stage at the annual Conservative Party conference and made clear she was still smarting from her banishment from office nine years ago. In a speech, she trod underfoot her party's attempts to keep Britain relatively in league with the European Union.

Thatcher Contradicts Party On Touchy Issue of Europe Former Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher took center stage at the annual Conservative Party conference and made clear she was still smarting from her banishment from office nine years ago. In a speech, she trod underfoot her party's attempts to keep Britain relatively in league with the European Union.
Aftermath of London Crash The death toll from the train crash in London rose to at least 70 and the fate of 100 more people remained unclear, according to police.
New U.S. Bombs Against Iraq American fighters patrolling northern Iraq have a new weapon -- concrete bombs -- in an effort to minimize civilian casualties.
Israel to Observe Arab Deaths Education Minister Yossi Sarid has recommended that a massacre of Israeli Arabs by border policemen in 1956 be marked in Israeli classrooms for the first time.

Jordanian King to Visit U.S. Jordan's King Abdullah set out for a week of Washington meetings capped by a session at the White House. In remarks before his departure, he said his main goal was to maintain the momentum toward the broad regional peace settlement.

Russia Expands Chechen War Russian forces have expanded their operation in Chechnya, moving more troops in from the west, after seizing control of the northern part of the republic, Chechen commanders say.

Deal on Test-Ban Treaty Stalled An agreement to delay a Senate vote on a treaty banning underground nuclear tests stalled. Republicans want to avoid having the pact become a campaign issue and Democrats hope to keep the accord alive next year.

Early Election Results in India Ballot-counting in the third national elections in three years got under way and partial results showed the Hindu nationalist-led coalition taking a lead against the alliance headed by the Congress Party.

House Votes Tax Breaks To Buy Health Insurance The House, in a largely partisan vote of 227 to 205, passed a bill giving tax breaks to help millions of people buy health insurance. But it also took a procedural step that jeopardizes legislation on patients' rights and H.M.O. regulation. The White House promised a veto of the tax break bill unless changes were made.
Capitol Deal on New Fighter The House and Senate struck a deal that would let the $70 billion F-22 Air Force fighter go into production if it passed stringent flight tests.

Warning to Cruise Industry Senator John McCain told the cruise industry that Congress might restrict access to American ports unless the companies did a better job of abiding by United States laws and insuring the safety of passengers.

Military Code and Bias Crimes President Clinton signed an executive order toughening military penalties for crimes motivated by hatred based on the victim's race, religion, ethnicity or sexual orientation.

Views on Jews and Communism Newly released tapes again depict President Richard M. Nixon as un-self-consciously anti-Semitic, informing aides at one point that the Communist conspiracy in the United States was made up almost entirely of Jews.

DNA Used to Charge 'John Doe' A prosecutor in Wisconsin has filed rape and kidnapping charges against a suspect known only by his DNA code, which was extracted from semen. The purpose is to keep the time limit for bringing a rape charge from running out. Every month, an F.B.I. computer will compare the DNA code with thousands of samples from felons and crime scene evidence.

Mixed Findings on Acid Rain An international team of scientists reported a nearly universal decrease in Europe and North America in the levels of sulfates, the major acidifying pollutant deposited by acid rain in surface water. But the researchers did not see a decrease in overall acidity, the sign of true recovery, in all regions.

Double-Parking Crackdown Ends Cherished Precedent Police officers conducting a City Hall-ordered campaign against double-parking issued 8,288 traffic tickets on Tuesday, including 2,230 tickets for double-parked cars and 1,003 for double-parked trucks. The campaign drew particular scorn on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, where residents said double-parking on street-cleaning days has long been overlooked by the authorities.

Missing the Economic Boom Nearly one in four New York City residents had incomes below the poverty threshold last year, a rate that has barely dipped since the last recession and that is twice as high as the national average, an analysis of census data concludes.
Pattern Sought in Killings The police are investigating whether the strangulation and slashing killings of four women in a small section of Brooklyn are linked.

Subway Pushing Murder Trial Andrew Goldstein, a 30-year-old diagnosed schizophrenic with a history of being shunted in and out of mental institutions, will go on trial today in the subway pushing death of Kendra Webdale, above, in January.
Ethics Law Overhaul Urged Gov. John G. Rowland of Connecticut called on legislators to undertake a sweeping examination of state election and ethics laws.
Ginsberg Memorabilia for Sale The estate of the poet Allen Ginsberg is carrying out his wishes and auctioning off his belongings at Sotheby's in Manhattan today.
Mets, Red Sox and Astros Lose Cleveland beat Boston, 3-2, to open their playoff. Atlanta defeated Houston, 5-1, and Arizona stopped the Mets, 7-1, to tie both series at 1-1.

Scrutiny for Big Mergers Federal officials have begun setting the conditions they will impose on a wave of proposed mergers that promise to consolidate, blur and redefine the telephone, cable and broadcasting industries.

AT&T Cable TV Chief Leaving AT&T said the head of its cable-television operation, Leo J. Hindery Jr., had decided to leave. Many analysts and others said Mr. Hindery, 51, had developed an irrevocable personality conflict with AT&T's chairman, C. Michael Armstrong.

Datek Chairman Resigning Jeffrey A. Citron, 29, agreed to step down and relinquish any role in Datek Online Holdings, which he helped fashion into a Wall Street powerhouse but which has become the subject of a several inquiries.
Editorials: U.N. governance in East Timor; the fight for patients' rights; restoring Radio City; Eleanor Randolph on George Pataki's dreams.
